intro: Vasconcellea microcarpa subsp. baccata, commonly known as the black star apple, is a tropical fruit-bearing plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its large, elliptical leaves and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant produces a unique fruit with a rough, spiny exterior and a sweet, juicy pulp containing numerous seeds. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often grown for its ornamental value and edible fruit. The subspecies is distinguished by its darker, more pronounced fruit color compared to other varieties of Vasconcellea.
